Grey to state, for the information of the Lords Commissioners of His Majesty’s Treasury, that his attention has been from time to time called to the desirability of im proving the quarantine arrangements in the Persian Gulf. The special position held by this country in the Persian Gulf has recently been emphasized in connec tion v/ith the Anglo-Russian Agreements and Sir E.Grey agrees with the Secretary of State for India, with whom he has been in correspondence, that no effort should be spared to maintain the status* quo in those waters. Since the British authorities were intrusted by the Persian Government with the sanitary service in 1896 foreign shipping in the Gulf has increased, and His The Secretary to the Treasury.Hie Majesty's Minister at Tehran reports that frequent attempts have lately been made by the representatives of other Powers to influence the Sanitary Council at Tehran against a continuance of the existing system. He points out that a large measure of political and conmercial control naturally follows from the control of sanitary measures and that the Influence and prestige enjoyed by European doctors in Persia are hardly in ferior to those of Political Agents. In Sir C. Spring- Ice's opinion a general attack on the British Sanitary Service in the Gulf Ports is not unlikely in the near future, and an improvement in the efficiency of the service would be a powerful argument in favour of the maintenance of the present system. The outbreak of plague at Bahrein a few months ago brought into notice the deficiency in the disinfecting equipment of the southern ports, but it is out of the question to expect the Persian Government either to im- P ve the se.vice themselves or to pay for its improve ment at the hands of British medical officers. The only alternative therefore is that the service shouldbe strengthened end rendered more efficient at the joint expense of His Majesty's Government and the Government of India, unless the quarantine service of Persia is to pass into the hands of an International body on which British shipping Interests would be able to exercise an utterly inadequate influence and which would certainly be swayed by political motives rather than by legitimate considerations based on re quirements of public health. The Government of India are willing to bear half the cost of the requisite arrangements, provided that His Majesty's Government will defray the other half. As will be seen by reference to the accompanying copy of a letter from the India Office, the Government of India estimate that the cost of the most pressing requirements will amount to £2,250 initial cost and £1,101 recurring. WITH reference to my despatch No. 156 of the 16th ultimo, on the subject of the proposed improvements in the quarantine service in the Gulf, I have the honour to inform you that 1 called M. de Hartwig’s attention, in a private and friendly con versation, to the attitude adopted in the Committee of the Sanitary Council towards the proposal. I said that Dr. Schneider had pointed out that improvements were necessary, and that, as the Persian Government would be obviously unable to meet the necessary expenditure, the British Government, which was mainly interested in navigation in the Gulf, and whose officials were charged with the direction of sanitary measures, should itself provide the means for the proposed improvements. The Russian doctor, however, had taken a line which seemed to indicate that the proposals made were of a political character, and had himself suggested that the Belgian Customs officials should take a more active part in the Quarantine Administration. I added that the object of the British Government in giving a favourable consideration to Dr. Schneider’s proposals had nothing to do with politics, and that they desired to maintain the status quo in the Persian Gulf, a desire which I understood to be shared by M. Isvolsky. M. de Hartwig informed me that he was not conversant with the question, which he did not himself understand (the matter is, I believe, left in M. Passek’s hands). He entirely shared my desire that no question of a political nature should be raised in the Sanitary Council. As the outbreak of plague was now at an end, it would, he thought, be advisable to let the matter drop, and we accordingly agreed to instruct our Delegates not to raise the question in the Council. I spoke to the President, who informed me that the Special Committee had gone far beyond the very modest programme which he had himselt submitted, in concert with Dr. Williams, the Englishman charged with the supervision of quarantine in the Gulf; that he preferred not to bring the Report of the Committee before the Council, but Govi had approached Persian Government would provide the necessary funds; this, he said, they were unable to do. He therefore advised that a scheme of smaller scope should be drawn up. The matter was then dropped without any discussion, and without the Report of the Committee having been read. I understand from him and the French Minister that the Russian Minister has complained of his attitude as being “ too English. M. de Hartwig seemed to regard the proposals as designed to increase English influence in the Gulf, and to be unacceptable to Russia. Dr. Eriestmantel, the Austrian Delegate, pointed out to me that he was himself responsible for the extended programme of reforms. His object was to provide against the danger to Europe which would result as soon as railway communication between Anatolia and the Gulf was completed. He had been much struck by the violent anti-English tone of the communications of the Russian doctor, who imported political animus into the discussions which created a painful impression among h colleagues. He quite understood that the object of my Government in entertaining Dr. Schneider’s proposals had been purely philanthropic, but he agreed that for the present it would be perhaps better to allow the subject to drop. He suggested, however, that the British Government should provide stoves for Bunder Abbas and Mohammerah as well as for Bahrein, in which latter place they no doubt could do what they waute without fear of interferenc e. mods.abstract: The volume contains part one of the subject file 2908/1907 Persian Gulf: Quarantine. This part contains papers regarding proposals for the improvement of the Persian Gulf Quarantine Service. It therefore contains discussion between British officials over the provision of finance, personnel, and equipment to facilitate improvements. The supply of stoves (for Jask, Bundar Abbas [Bandar-e ʻAbbās], Lingah [Bandar-e-Lengeh], Mohammerah, Bushire, and Bahrain) and a Clayton disinfection apparatus by the Government of India accounts for a significant amount of correspondence. Some discussion surrounding possible threats to British control of the Quarantine service can also be found in the file.Printed copies of the minutes of the Sanitary Council for the Empire of Persia are included for the meetings: 29 June 1907 (folios 141-143), 5 August 1907 (folios 144-145), 2 September 1907 (folios 133-135), 4 November 1907 (folios 81-83), and 2 December 1907 (folios 84-86). These documents are written in French. A note from Dr Jean-Etienne Justin Schneider, President of the Sanitation Council, on proposed improvements to the Quarantine Service can be found on folio 196-198. This note is also in French.Printed copies of telegrams regarding a plague outbreak in Bahrain in 1907 can be found between folios 183-187.Towards the front of the file are a small number of papers related to a proposal to withdraw the mobile assistant medical officer – posted to Bushire under the improvement programme – from the Persian Gulf in 1909.The main correspondents are as follows: the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs (Sir Edward Grey), HM Minister at Tehran (Sir Cecil Arthur Spring-Rice), the Chargé d'affaires at Tehran (Charles Murray Marling), the Under-Secretary of State for India (Arthur Godley), and officials from the Foreign Office (Louis Mallet and Sir Walter Langley). Occasional reference is also made to the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf (Major Percy Zachariah Cox) and the Government of India.Each part includes a divider which gives the subject and part numbers, the year the subject file was opened, the subject heading, and a list of correspondence references contained in that part by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
